Metric statement: "Road/trail proximity or density as an indicator of watershed development and potential sediment/pollutant delivery. Distance from the project reach to the nearest road and/or planned road expansion. Closer roads can increase stormwater inputs, constrain floodplains, and contribute sediment and pollutants. Road density within the contributing watershed or buffer. Higher road density can increase runoff, fragment riparian areas, and deliver sediment/pollutants. Degree of land development/disturbance in the watershed and/or near the project reach (e.g., urban areas, industrial sites, oil/gas, mining, timber harvest). Increased development can alter runoff, sediment delivery, and water quality."
How to measure: "Use roads/trails GIS and recent imagery to summarize proximity and/or density within the watershed or specified buffer. Assign the condition class using the bin thresholds for this metric. Measure the minimum distance from the project reach (or riparian buffer) to mapped roads using GIS and/or recent imagery. Where specified, incorporate information on proposed road expansion. Assign the condition class using the bin thresholds for this metric. Using a roads GIS layer, calculate total road length divided by watershed area (or within the specified buffer). Assign the condition class using the bin thresholds for this metric. Review recent imagery and available land use/permit data to characterize development intensity in the watershed and within the specified distance of the project reach (e.g., 1 mile). Assign the condition class using the bin thresholds for this metric."

Function statement: Wetlands and storage features store floodwater, recharge groundwater, sustain baseflow, and provide low-velocity habitat.
Metric statement: Moderate floods (~1-5 yr) reach the floodplain, providing water retention/infiltration per regional norms.
How to measure: Identify bankfull indicators and recent high-water marks and compare to bankfull elevation. Corroborate with a nearby gage bankfull or recurrence estimate where available.

Poor: Poor: Rarely or never overbanking below about 10+ yr events. Deep incision or levees block moderate floods. (Suggested index range 0.0-0.39)

Function statement: Ensures habitat availability and water quality during low water levels, and indicates non-storm conditions experienced the majority of the time.
Metric statement: "Evaluates whether the reach maintains adequate wetted depth and continuity during low flow by integrating pool depth, wetted length, exposed bed, and Q90/Q10 differences. Extent to which water remains in contact with both banks and low benches during low flow, sustaining edge habitat and exchange."
How to measure: "Estimate percent of channel length wetted at typical low-flow conditions and document with photos where feasible. Count pools that remain connected versus isolated at low flow and note dominant disconnection causes. Estimate percent of bed exposed during low flow using field photos or dry-season imagery where available."
Good: Good: >75% of channel wetted at normal low flow (or dryness is normal if ephemeral). (Suggested index range 0.70-1.0)
Fair: Fair: 25-75% wetted. (Suggested index range 0.40-0.69)
Poor: Poor: <25% wetted, or mostly disconnected pools in a historically perennial reach. (Suggested index range 0.0-0.39)

Metric statement: Moderate floods (~1-2 yr) overtop banks unless valley is naturally confined.

Fair: Fair: About 3-5 yr floods are needed. / About 5-10 yr floods are needed. (Suggested index range 0.40-0.69)

Function statement: Peak flows reshape channel without chronic instability, redistribute wood and sediment, reset habitats, and supply nutrients to floodplains.

Use imagery change detection to identify fresh bars or scour after moderate floods and confirm in the field where possible. Compare bankfull width and depth to regional curves for drainage area and slope and flag large departures."

Fair: Fair: Slight mismatch. Bed moves below or above expected flows. / Marked mismatch. Bed is often locked or frequently scoured. (Suggested index range 0.40-0.69)

Function statement: Frequent overbank flows reduce flood peaks, support riparian vegetation, create off-channel refugia, and extend nutrient processing time.
Metric statement: "Stable, not heavily dredged/incised, allowing normal overbank flows/meanders unless dredging is historical. Channel is not deeply incised; moderate floods access a broad floodplain, matching reference conditions. 1-2 yr floods routinely access the floodplain, matching reference inundation patterns."
How to measure: "Identify incision, dredging, levees, and spoil banks from imagery and confirm in the field or with historical sources where feasible. Compute entrenchment ratio as flood-prone width (often about 2x bankfull depth) divided by bankfull width using DEM or LiDAR cross sections and bankfull indicators. Map bankfull inundation extent using a DEM and bankfull flow estimate and compare to mapped floodplain layers as a proxy for moderate-flood access."
Good: Good: Stable channel that is not incised or dredged with frequent floodplain access. (Suggested index range 0.70-1.0)
Fair: Fair: Slight channelization or partial dredging. / Heavily modified or incised channel with limited floodplain access. (Suggested index range 0.40-0.69)
Poor: Poor: Deeply dredged or channelized reach with little functional floodplain. (Suggested index range 0.0-0.39)

Function statement: Surface water-groundwater exchange moderates temperature, transforms nutrients, supplies oxygen, and supports aquatic life.

Fair: Fair: Partially permeable soils or some clogging. / Mostly fine fill or bedrock that limits infiltration. (Suggested index range 0.40-0.69)
Poor: Poor: Heavily compacted or lined soils with minimal subsurface exchange. (Suggested index range 0.0-0.39)

Metric statement: "Diverse bedforms enhance surface-subsurface exchange, matching reference morphology. Springs/seeps/subsurface flow show active hyporheic exchange, matching local reference."

Function statement: Long-term changes in channel size and slope maintain dynamic equilibrium and diverse habitats while interacting with the floodplain.
Metric statement: "Channel is stable/recovered (Stage I/VI or 0,1,6,8), not actively degrading, unless partial evolution is normal. No active headcuts or fully stabilized ones; no ongoing incision or bank widening. Channel shows vegetated benches/floodplain formation, indicating recovery from incision/widening. Bank erosion/migration rates match natural reference; no excessive widening unless historically typical."
How to measure: "Assess channel evolution stage using field indicators or recent geomorphic reports. Use desktop review only for coarse screening. Locate headcuts or knickpoints and estimate migration using multi-date elevation or imagery. Confirm in the field. Identify vegetated benches or inset floodplains and track their extent using imagery and elevation profiles where available. Map active channel edges across years and compute width change using imagery and field indicators where feasible."
Good: Good: Stable or re-stabilized channel (Stage I or VI). (Suggested index range 0.70-1.0)
Fair: Fair: Partially recovered channel (often Stage V). / Actively widening or incising (often Stage III-IV). (Suggested index range 0.40-0.69)

Function statement: Examines the role of bank processes and erosion in channel change. Observes patterns in sinuosity and curvature affecting habitat complexity.
Metric statement: "Integrates bank geometry, rooting, surface protection, raw or failing banks, and hardening to summarize erosion risk and sediment delivery. Compares meander migration rates and cutoff frequency to reference behavior; excessive migration or avulsions indicate instability."

Fair: Fair: Some armoring or partial vegetation coverage. / Large portion of banks is armored or vegetation is sparse. (Suggested index range 0.40-0.69)
Poor: Poor: Failing armoring or widespread bare banks with severe instability. (Suggested index range 0.0-0.39)

Map connected side channels and verify likely connection thresholds at about bankfull stage using field checks or elevation profiles. How to measure: "Delineate the contributing watershed and compute percent forest land cover using a land cover dataset (e.g., NLCD). Assign the condition class using the bin thresholds for this metric. Using recent imagery and/or land cover data, delineate the riparian corridor along the reach (or specified stream length) and quantify corridor width/continuity (e.g., percent of stream length meeting a minimum corridor width). Assign the condition class using the bin thresholds for this metric."

Function statement: Balanced sediment supply and transport preserves bed elevations, substrate sizes, spawning/benthic habitats, and supports riparian succession.

Delineate bar types (point, mid-channel, lateral) and compare to expected morphology for the channel type. Screen stream power using discharge and slope and compare with observed bars or scour. Detailed transport modeling is beyond screening."
